Dear Sheffield City Council,
I am requesting information under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 regarding potholes in the council area. I understand different councils may define potholes and repairs differently, so I would appreciate clarification if your council applies a specific threshold for logging or repairing potholes.
I would like to request the following data for the past five calendar years (2020–2024):
1. The number of potholes recorded each year, including potholes reported by the public and confirmed through council inspections (if these are reported differently)
2. The number of individual potholes repaired each year, including temporary repairs (e.g., patching) and permanent repairs (e.g., resurfacing). Note this refers to the number of individual potholes that were repaired, not the total number of repairs.
3. The total annual cost of pothole repairs, if available.
If the data is recorded differently, I would appreciate any comparable figures you can provide, along with a brief explanation of how pothole reports and repairs are logged in your system.
If this request exceeds the cost limit under the FOI Act, please let me know how it may be refined to remain within the statutory limits.
Thank you for your help; please let me know if you require any clarification or have any questions.
All the best,
Jamie Dixon

Dear Jamie Dixon,
Thank you for your request for information relating to pothole reports and

Dear Jamie Dixon,
Thank you for your request for information relating to pothole reports and
repairs which we received on 14/02/2025.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
I would like to request the following data for the past five calendar
years (2020–2024):
1. The number of potholes recorded each year, including potholes reported
by the public and confirmed through council inspections (if these are
reported differently)
2020 2021 2022 2023 2024
7,069 8,275 8,726 12,569 14,240
These figures include pothole ‘Defects’ raised internally, as well as
pothole ‘Enquiries’ raised by members of the public. There may be some
duplication where the same defect has been reported multiple times.
The figures contain reports which have been classed as ‘permanently
resolved’.  They also include reports which are not classed as
‘permanently resolved’ due to them, for example, being below the threshold
for intervention, could not be located or not on the highway network
maintainable under the Highway Maintenance Contract with Amey Hallam
Highways Ltd.
Please note that while we do hold this information, we are refusing your
request under Regulation 12(4)(b) of the Environmental Information
Regulations 2004 on the grounds that it would be manifestly unreasonable
to comply with the request. We do not record this information in a format
that allows us to produce an electronic report of this and therefore, we
would have to carry out a manual search of each record. The figures above
relate to the number of reports (Enquiries and Defects) relating to
potholes and it is possible for one report to include more than one
pothole. The number of individual potholes is not in a readily searchable
format.  To calculate the number of individual potholes, each pothole
report would have to be manually checked.  It is estimated that checking
would take approximately two minutes per report (which would include
checking linked jobs, photos, different location descriptions, etc) which
would total approximately 1,695 hours.
Regulation 12(4)(b) is subject to a public interest test. Factors in
favour of disclosure are that disclosure promotes openness and
transparency. Factors in favour of maintaining the exception are that it
is not in the public interest to spend such a large amount of officer time
on providing this information, as this would come at a large cost to the
council and would divert officers from being able to carry out other work.
On balance, the council believes that the public interest lies in
maintaining the exception.
2. The number of individual potholes repaired each year, including
temporary repairs (e.g., patching) and permanent repairs (e.g.,
resurfacing). Note this refers to the number of individual potholes
that were repaired, not the total number of repairs.
2020 2021 2022 2023 2024
11,338 8,681 8,725 10,853 15,066
Please note that these figures relate to the number of reports relating to
potholes which have been classed as ‘permanently resolved’.   It is
possible for one report to contain more than one pothole.
Please note that while we do hold this information, we are refusing your
request under Regulation 12(4)(b) of the Environmental Information
Regulations 2004 on the grounds that it would be manifestly unreasonable
to comply with the request. The information relating to the number of
individual potholes is not in a readily searchable format.  To calculate
the number of individual potholes, each pothole enquiry would have to be
manually checked. It is estimated that checking would take approximately
two minutes per enquiry (which would include checking linked jobs, photos,
different location descriptions, etc) which would total approximately
1,822 hours.
Regulation 12(4)(b) is subject to a public interest test. Factors in
favour of disclosure are that disclosure promotes openness and
transparency. Factors in favour of maintaining the exception are that it
is not in the public interest to spend such a large amount of officer time
on providing this information, as this would come at a large cost to the
council and would divert officers from being able to carry out other work.
On balance, the council believes that the public interest lies in
maintaining the exception.
3. The total annual cost of pothole repairs, if available.
Sheffield City Council has a Private Finance Initiative contract with Amey
Hallam Highways Ltd for the delivery of a complete highway maintenance
service which includes all highway maintenance activities such as street
lighting, street cleaning, repair of potholes, carriageway and footway
resurfacing, signal maintenance etc.  Payments made by the Council under
the contract do not relate to the provision of specific items of work.
Instead, a single payment is made for each month of the 25-year term of
the contract.  As a result, we do not have a figure for the costs incurred
by Amey for individual operations such as the repair of potholes.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
